elements.short_title: It was Week 13 of 2024 at Near Future Laboratory, and some things happened.
elements.salutation:
You are one of 17,000 subscribers who appreciate the value of a futures-oriented mindset.

Please consider becoming a participant in the Near Future Laboratory creative collaborative by becoming a supporter on Patreon.

It was the 13th week of two thousand and twenty four and a recurring theme was the recognition that an inability to dream of the world one wants to inhabit is a good way to ensure that one will never hold that world closely enough to make it a lived reality.

What took them so long to put wheels on luggage? I mean‚Ä¶it‚Äôs not like they had to invent anything.

How could it be that ‚Äòjogging‚Äô wasn‚Äôt something that, you know ‚Äî¬†just *was?

If you cannot sense, see, imagine, feel what could be, it's highly likely that it will not become a lived reality.

We celebrate dreamers, those who convince themselves of the possibility of their dreams despite the doubters.

In the imposed doubting lies the perspiration we often hear of ‚Äî the hard work of translating the not true *yet into something you can point at and discuss, and hold, and turn on, and try, and ponder what the world would like if‚Ä¶

We celebrate dreamers because they do the hard work of translating the dream into reality, which then becomes the surprising and exciting, perhaps seasoned with skepticism. Onward the dream floats in this new stew of confusion as reality mingles with the dream poking and prodding it, checking to see if it is in fact worthy of occupying the reality of more than the dreamer.

Should the dream prove to be resonant enough to reveal its practical utility or for its resonance and ability to fill the various voids, gaps, and longings in our psyches, the dream becomes normal ‚Äî¬†no longer a dream but the thing that fills the gap between what was and the future.

If thinking and arranging your understanding of what is and what could be, or understanding the methods and techniques you need to appreciate how to see and sense the unanticipated and unexpected possibilities that we casually refer to as ‚Äòthe future‚Äô, then you should join the Near Future Laboratory, participate in our futuring and sense-making programs, platforms, and projects, and learn more about the ways we bring Imagination and Structure into rich, world-changing collaboration. Everything that will be once was the not true *yet. It‚Äôs Time to Imagine Harder. We‚Äôve got some serious work to do. We need your help.

How?

Become a part of the NFL Discord by becoming a sustaining member at patreon.com/nearfuturelaboratory

If you don't already have our books and work kits, pick them up from our 100% independently designed, manufactured, and published books and tools over at shop.nearfuturelaboratory.com

connect with us to help you make sense of your organization's future. And please amplify this by sharing with friends and colleagues.

elements.title: Creative Vitality‚Ñ¢ Summit 2024
elements.subtitle: April 9 ‚Äì 10, 2024
elements.main_copy:
Check this out ‚Äî I'll be hosting a discussion of creativity in the era of AI at the Creative Vitality‚Ñ¢ Summit.
"What's that," you ask?
Now in its third year, the Creative Vitality‚Ñ¢ Summit will bring together artists, designers, technologists, arts advocates, and policy experts to consider the impact of new economic models, new forms of investment, and technological change in arts, culture, and the creative economy. Registration for this virtual event is free and is now open!

elements.link_text: New to the MoMA Permanent Collection
elements.title: Priscilla Huggable Atomic Mushroom
elements.subtitle: Designs for Fragile Personalities in Anxious Times Project
elements.main_copy: Priscila Huggable Atomic Mushroom is part of the project Design for Fragile Personalities in Anxious Times, a collection of speculative prescription products meant to address various anxieties. Anthony Dunne, Fiona Raby, Michael Anastassiades explore the psychological connections between objects and their users. A comforting plushy allowing you to embrace their fears of nuclear war.

elements.link_text: Join Mike Milley Mercedes-Benz's Principal Futurist & Scott Smith author of Future Cultures
elements.title: SuperSeminar 007 - Futures & Foresight
elements.subtitle: Learn how futures practitioners do what they do, where they do it.
elements.main_copy: SuperSeminar is the opposite of things like TED, where you hear remarkable insights and perspectives from remarkable people ‚Äî and don't get to engage in meaningful conversation with them. They're there..and then they're gone. SuperSeminar is not TED. It's a Salon-like discussion with two domain experts presenting short, incisive, evocative conversation starts ‚Äî and then attendees and presenters engage in discussion. Limited seats. The value is in the discussion.
What the heck is this here?

elements.title: Jay Springett
elements.subtitle: Writer, podcaster, musician, strategist.
elements.author: @Jaymo
elements.main_copy:
Jay Springett is a writer, podcaster, and strategist. He was an early voice in the solarpunk movement.
His new podcast is a must for whatever podcast nozzle you listen from ‚Äî Experience.Computer recently concluded its first season. It's an interview show about creativity, imagination and aphantasia - an inability to summon visual images in the mind. It's all interlinked. I'm trying to catch up and going backwards, have been listening to the episode with director and animator Kirsten Lepore.

elements.title: Seen in the Near Future Laboratory Discord
elements.subtitle: Not The Usual Signals

elements.post_copy: Max Read critiques Kyle Chayka's book 'Filterworld', which argues that algorithms have led to a homogenized culture, expressing skepticism about the novelty and significance of this assertion and questioning the extent to which algorithms alone are responsible for cultural homogeneity.

elements.user_callout: In the üéß-podcasts channel @Drew Wiberg posted this
elements.post_copy: Skipping ahead an hour in this Lex Freidman interview with Sam Altman so we can learn, from Sam, why GPT-4 ‚Äòsucks‚Äô.

Jon Corbett's work includes the development of Cree# and Ancestral Code, programming languages that integrate Cree language and cultural concepts, and his ongoing PhD research toward an Indigenous Coding Framework aimed at enabling Indigenous communities to embed their languages, logic, and values into programming.

The thing I hate the most about advertising is that it attracts all the bright, creative and ambitious young people, leaving us mainly with the slow and self-obsessed to become our artists.. Modern art is a disaster area. Never in the field of human history has so much been used by so many to say so little.‚Äï Banksy

John Maeda's 2024 "Design Against AI" segment emphasizes the importance of understanding computational thinking, preparing for the transformative impact of AI on design and tech careers, and advocating for the use of AI in a manner that is fair and inclusive.
The 'Against' in the title is a bit misleading given the content Maeda offers. That said, being 'against' AI is a bit like being against breakfast. It's here. It happens. Now..what, when, why, and how we eat breakfast is the more useful conversation.
‚ÄîJulian

An oldie but a goodie: Terra0 is an innovative blockchain project that aims to create a self-governing, self-owning, self-exploiting forest, enabling the ecosystem to interact with economic markets autonomously.

elements.user_callout: In the üçü-augmented-and-also-virtual channel @Brandel Zachernuk posted this
elements.link_text: Introducing Natural Input for WebXR in Apple Vision Pro
elements.post_copy: Apple Vision Pro introduces natural input for WebXR on visionOS, offering a more intuitive and privacy-centric method of interaction through transient-pointer input, enhancing the immersive experience by combining eye and hand gestures, as detailed in a collaborative effort outlined by Ada Rose Cannon and Brandel Zachernuk on WebKit's blog.

elements.link_text: I made a custom ASIC: World's first of its kind
elements.post_copy: bitluni, details the process of designing and manufacturing a custom ASIC ‚Äî prehaps the first of its kind?? People like to say that. We feel a need to be the one that changes the conversation, or shows the unexpected/unanticipate/previously unseen, don't we? Why is that? Vanity? Desire for impact? To gain notoriety?
